block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Music
COMMUNITY THEATER OF MORRISTOWN Michael Feinstein. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $40 to $60. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 539-8008.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Music
COMMUNITY THEATER OF MORRISTOWN Michael Feinstein. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $40 to $60. 100 South Street, Morristown. (973) 539-8008.
FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY OF ELIZABETH Sammy Lee, pianist. Saturday at 2:15 p.m. 11 South Broad Street, Elizabeth. (908) 354-6060.

McCARTER THEATER ''Chanticleer.'' Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 and $33. Dianne Reeves Quintet, with Brad Mehldau. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 and $28. ''Bernadette Peters. . .Gala Fund-Raiser for the McCarter Theater,'' with 30-piece orchestra. Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $60. 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.
MONTCLAIR PUBLIC LIBRARY Montclair's Monday Night Music series, featuring Lisle Atkinson and the Neo Bass Ensemble. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. 50 South Fullerton Street, Montclair. (973) 509-4910.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Family Concerts: Music for Young People.'' Saturday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $11 and $16. ''Symphony Night at the Movies.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $14 to $55. India Bamboleo. Next Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets: $13 to $45. Prudential Hall. Prudential Hall. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
PEDDIE SCHOOL Anoushka Shankar. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20. William Mount-Burke Theater, Richard L. Swig Arts Center, South Main Street, Hightstown. (609) 490-7550.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY RICHARDSON AUDITORIUM The Brentano String Quartet. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Free. University Concerts Jazz event, featuring Jerry Gonzalez and the Fort Apache Band. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $17 to $26; $2 for students. Alexander Hall, Princeton. (609) 258-5000.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY TAPLIN AUDITORIUM ''Friends of Music at Princeton'' event featuring Victor Jannett, baritone, and Eve Kochen Budnick, pianist. Friday at 8 p.m. Free. Taplin Auditorium, Fine Hall. Washington Road, Princeton. (609) 258-4239.
RAMAPO COLLEGE The Ahn Trio. Friday at 8 p.m. Berrie Center for the Performing Arts, 505 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah. (201) 684-7844.

ST. PETER'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH Choral Concert featuring the Choir of Men and Girls, Washington National Cathedral. Friday at 7:30 p.m. Suggested donation: $10; $8 for students and older people. Carillon Concert, featuring John Widman, guest carillonneur. Next Sunday at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $8; $5 for students and older people. 70 Maple Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-0555.

SHANGHAI JAZZ Shanghai Jazz debut of Rene Marie, vocalist. Today at 6 p.m. Dr. Billy Taylor Trio. Tuesday and Wednesday at 7 p.m. Morris Nanton Trio. Thursday at 7 p.m. The Earl May Quintet, featuring Catherine Russell, vocalist. Friday at 6:45 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. and Saturday at 6:30 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. No cover. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.

SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION Lorrie Morgan with Delbert McClinton, guest. Friday, 7:30 p.m. to 10 p.m. Somerset County Park Commission Fall Festival featuring Felix Cavaliere's Rascals, Blood Sweat and Tears, and Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. Tickets: $10 to $45. Somerset County Ballpark, Bridgwater. (908) 252-0700 or (908) 722-1200.
STANHOPE HOUSE Oktoberfest, featuring Billy Hector Band, Fat Mama, Addison Grove Project and Devine Afflatus. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $10. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.

STATE THEATER Iceland Symphony Orchestra. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $45. ''Family Concerts: Music for Young People.'' Next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $11 and $16. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.

STOCKTON PERFORMING ARTS CENTER R. Carlos Nakai, flutist, with William Eaton, lyraharp guitarist, and Will Clipman, percussion. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 (orchestra), $20 (mezzanine). The Richard Stockton College of New Jersey, Jim Leeds Road, Pomona. (609) 652-9000.
TRENTON WAR MEMORIAL ''Symphonic Night at the Movies.'' Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $14 to $55. Lafayette and Willow Streets, Trenton. (609) 984-8400.
UNION COUNTY ARTS CENTER Westfield Symphony Orchestra and the Arbor Chamber Music Society. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $40. 1601 Irving Street, Rahway. (732) 499-8226.
UNITY CONCERTS OF NEW JERSEY The American String Quartet. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $30. Mount Hebron Auditorium, Montclair. (973) 744-6770.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER ''Brooklyn Bluegrass Maestro'' Orrin Star, in concert. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10. Watchung Circle, 18 Stirling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.

WILLIAM PATERSON UNIVERSITY 2000 Midday Artists Series, featuring Karen Demsey, flutist, and Greg Giannascoli, marimba and percussionist. Thursday at 12:30 p.m. Tickets: $3. Fall 2000 Jazz Room Series: Eric Alexander Quintet featuring Harold Mabern. Today at 4 p.m. Mulgrew Mill and Wingspan. Next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $12, $9 for William Paterson community. Shea Center for Performing Arts, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne. (973) 720-2371.
Theater

AMERICAN STAGE COMPANY ''Forever Plaid.'' Thursday through Oct. 22. Performances are Thursdays at 7:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. and Wednesday and Sunday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $30. Becton Hall, Fairleigh Dickinson University, 1000 River Road, Teaneck. (201) 692-7744.

CENTENARY PERFORMING ARTS GUILD Dodi Pettit and Friends -- ''A Country Evening With Broadway Flair.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12.50 for children under 12. 400 Jefferson Street, Hackettstown. (908) 979-0900.

ELIZABETH PLAYHOUSE ''The Youngest'' by Philip Barry. Through Oct. 15. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m.; and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $8; $6 for students and older people; $5 on Fridays. 1100 East Jersey Street, Elizabeth. (908) 355-0077.
JOHN HARMS CENTER FOR THE ARTS Liam Harney's ''Celticfusion.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $40. 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood. (201) 567-3600.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''The Whole Town's Talking'' Dinner Theater. Through Oct. 28. Mondays through Saturdays at 11 a.m.; Sundays at 3:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 6:30 p.m. Tickets: $35.50 to $39.50 (lunch); $41.50 to $45.50 (Sundays); $43 to $47 (Saturday evenings). Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.
LUMIA THEATER New Play Reading series, featuring ''Van Choc, Straw'' by Mark Dunn. Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Tickets: $7.50. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.

McCARTER THEATER ''The Odyssey.'' Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $26 to $42. Julio Bocca and Ballet Argentino. Wednesday and Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $33 and $36. Bale Folclorico da Bahia: Carnival 2000. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $27 and $30. Center for the Performing Arts, 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.
NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER Julio Bocca and Ballet Argentino. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10 to $42. Prudential Hall. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE ''Anything Goes'' starring Chita Rivera and Lee Roy Reams. Through Oct. 15. Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 p.m.; Thursday and Sunday matinees at 2 p.m.; and Saturday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Brookside Drive, Millburn. (973) 376-4343.
RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEW BRUNSWICK ''Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company.'' Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10 to $16. New Theater, Douglass Campus, New Brunswick. (732) 932-7511.
STATE THEATER ''Celticfusion.'' Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $34. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.
Museums and Galleries

BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB GALLERY ''Winning: Overcoming Obstacles.'' Wednesday through Nov. 8. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Route 206, Lawrenceville, three miles south of Princeton. (609) 252-6275.

CHAMOT GALLERY ''Paint and Clay,'' paintings by Richard Estell and sculptures by Bruce Morozko. Thursday through Nov. 12. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

CLIFTON ARTS CENTER ''Open Shutters,'' group show by the Clifton Camera Club. Through Oct. 15. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Clifton and Van Houten Avenues, Clifton. (973) 472-5499.
CORYELL GALLERY Charles R. Ross and Nancy Silvia, exhibitions. Through Nov. 12. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 8 Coryell Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-0804.

FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON UNIVERSITY ''A Florham Sketchbook,'' exhibit of pen and ink drawings by Floyd R. Gellerman. Through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays, 2 to 10 p.m.; Mondays through Thursdays, 8:30 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Fridays, 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. The library, 285 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 443-8515.

GALLERY OF SOUTH ORANGE ''Essex Exposed 2; a Juried Exhibition of Essex County Artists.'' Through Oct. 22. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. and 4 to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Baird Center, 5 Mead Street, South Orange. (973) 378-7754, extension 2.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''James Dinerstein: New Sculpture,'' works in cast bronze. Through April 8, 2001. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Runway: Photographs by Larry Fink,'' an exhibit of behind-the-scenes photos from the world of fashion and haute couture. Through Nov. 26. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

IN RARE FORM GALLERY ''All Chairs: Designs for 2001 and Beyond,'' works by the architect Matthew Hoey. Through Oct. 30. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. 14 Church Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-1006.

J. C. C. METROWEST ''Reflections on Kiddush Sets: Sterling Silver Judaica,'' by Leo Contini. Through Dec. 24. Marantz Art Gallery, J.C.C. of Metropolitan, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange. ''Life in Art: From the Gallery of Stan Kase Featuring Works by Scott Hanson, Marie Bobela and Jenny Stewart.'' Through Oct. 22. Gaelen Art Gallery, Lautenberg Family JCC of Greater Morris, 910 Route 10 East, Whippany. (973) 736-3200, ext. 330.

J.C.C. ON THE PALISADES ''Beijing Through the Mist of Time.'' Tuesday through Oct. 29. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m to 10 p.m.; Friday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Waltuch Gallery, 411 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 569-7900, extension 433.

JOHNSON & JOHNSON HEADQUARTERS GALLERY Barbara Weissberger, drawings. Through Oct. 13. New Jersey Photography Forum. Through Nov. 16. Call for appointment only. 1 Johnson and Johnson Plaza, New Brunswick. (732) 524-6957.

KEAN UNIVERSITY ''Design at the Millennium: The 100 Greatest Designs of the Past Thousand Years.'' Tuesday through Oct. 28. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 3 p.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m. Downs Hall, South Campus, Morris and North Avenues, near Elizabeth. (908) 527-3059.

LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES ''Cultural Weather Station,'' collaborative art program. Friday at 7:30 p.m. ''2000 Craft Gallery.'' Through Oct. 15. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.

MACCULLOCH HALL HISTORICAL MUSEUM ''Lasting Impressions,'' an exhibit on the history and techniques of printmaking. Through Jan. 14, 2001. Admission: $4; $3 for older people and students. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 45 Macculloch Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-2404.

MONMOUTH COUNTY HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION ''The Karagheusian Rug Mill: A Story of Immigration and Industry.'' Through July 31, 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $2; $1.50 for older people; $1 for those ages 6 to 18; free for children under 6. 70 Court Street, Freehold. (732) 462-1466.

MONMOUTH MUSEUM New Jersey Water Color Society: ''58th Annual Open Exhibition.'' Through Nov. 5. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4. 761 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft. (732) 747-2266.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Lyrical Visions: Music and Dance in American and Native American Art.'' ''Georgia O'Keeffe: The Artist's Landscape, Photographs by Todd Webb.'' Through Jan. 7, 2001. ''Croquet: The Art of Play.' Through Oct. 15 (course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.) Admission: $7; $4 for children. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MONTCLAIR STATE UNIVERSITY ''Survey of Contemporary African Art,'' more than 50 works by artists from Algeria, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria and Senegal. Through Oct. 20. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. University Gallery, Life Hall, Valley Road and Normal Avenue, Upper Montclair. (973) 655-7640.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Women's Work is Never Done,'' an exhibition on the history and impact of the women's suffrage movement in New Jersey. Through Jan. 28, 2001. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.
MORPETH GALLERY David Shevlino, paintings; Natalie Ferracci, sculpture. Through Oct. 22. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 43 West Broad Street, Hopewell. (609) 333-9393.

MORRIS MUSEUM New Jersey Arts Annual: ''Everything for the Home'' juried exhibition. Through Nov. 17. ''Art and Nature: The Hudson River School'' exhibition. Through Nov. 19. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

MUSEUM OF EARLY TRADES AND CRAFTS ''Time Made Visible: An Exhibit on Time and Timepieces.'' Through Dec. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $3.50; $2 for students, children over 5 and older people. Main Street at Green Village Road, Madison. (973) 377-2982.
NABISCO GALLERY ''Preserving the Garden: Saving New Jersey Landscape.'' Through Oct. 18. Hours: daily, noon to 4 p.m. 100 DeForest Avenue, East Hanover. (973) 503-2000.

NEW JERSEY CENTER FOR THE HEALING ARTS The Guild of Creative Art's ''Joy of Art'' combines with ''A Soothing Pastime'' show. Through Nov. 2. Opening Reception: today, 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 9:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. 23 Mechanic Street, Red Bank. (732) 747-2944.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Resource-Full New Jersey,'' an exhibition on natural resources, past and present, and land-use consequences. Through 2002. ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through March 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Leonard Baskin, Clarence Carter, Jacob Lawrence and George Segal: New Jersey Remembers.'' Through Oct. 22. ''Woven by Tradition and Design: A Selection of American Indian Weavings, Textiles and Baskets.'' Through Dec. 31. ''Click! The Marvelous in American Vernacular Photography.'' Through Dec. 31. ''Dinosaurs, Ammonites and Asteroids.'' Through Jan. 21, 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Katherine Choy: A Promise Unfulfilled'' ceramic showcase. Through Jan. 21, 2001. ''Treasures of 19th-Century American Art.'' Through Dec. 3. ''The Luminous Image, V,'' and exhibition of illuminated photography. Through Oct. 8. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NEWARK PUBLIC LIBRARY ''Spared Lives: The Actions of Three Portuguese Diplomats During World War II.'' Through Saturday at the Van Buren branch. Hours: Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Wednesdays, 1 p.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. 140 Van Buren Street, Newark. (973) 733-7750. ''Diamond of Hope and Glory: The Life and Times of Latin Americans in the Negro Leagues.'' Through Dec. 2. Hours: Mondays, Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. 2nd floor gallery, 5 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 733-7798.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART ''Art in Boxes: Hers and His Stories.'' Through Jan. 7, 2001. ''Fred Returns: Selected Works of Fred Noyes From the Permanent Collection.'' Saturday through Feb. 4, 20001. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM ''What Photographs Look Like.'' Through Oct. 15. ''Dutch Prints in the Golden Age.'' Through Nov. 5. ''Life in the Fin de Siecle: Lithographs of Toulouse-Lautrec.'' Through Oct. 29. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PRINTMAKING COUNCIL OF NEW JERSEY ''Dust Shaped Hearts'' by Don Camp -- A Collection of Casein and Earth Pigment Monoprints.'' ''Ulysses Suite'' by Julyen Norman -- woodcuts, and linoleum cuts depicting scenes from the classic novel by James Joyce. Through Oct. 14. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m. 440 River Road, North Branch. (908) 725-2110.

PUFFIN CULTURAL FORUM ''Sex, Lies and Politics: Cartoonists Shooting From the Hip,'' current and historic political cartoons. Through Oct. 29. Hours: Monday through Friday, 1 to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 20 East Oakdene Avenue, Teaneck. (201) 836-8923.

RAMAPO COLLEGE ''Distinctions,'' exhibit explores how people identify with and conform to a group. Through Oct. 20. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 1 to 5 p.m. Kresge and Pascal Galleries, Berrie Center for the Performing Arts, 505 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah. (201) 684-7147.

RIDER UNIVERSITY Marge Chavooshian, ''Paintings and Drawings.'' Through Oct. 22. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 2 to 8 p.m.; Fridays through Sundays, 2 to 5 p.m. University Gallery, Route 206, Lawrenceville. (609) 896-5168.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN ''Every Picture Tells a Story,'' an exhibit that explores storytelling through narrative art. Through Nov. 11. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. Stedman Gallery, Third Street between Cooper Street and Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6350.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK ''Carrie Yamaoka: New Paintings.'' Through Oct. 13. Robeson Center Art Gallery, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, Newark. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. (973) 353-5119, ext. 32. ''Faces of the Ironbound: Newark 1937-1939.'' Tuesday through Dec. 14. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m. to midnight; Friday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 10 p.m. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5111.

SETON HALL UNIVERSITY ''A Response to Emotionalism: Recent Works by Eastern European Artists.'' Through Oct. 27. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Walsh Library Gallery, 400 South Orange Avenue, South Orange. (973) 275-2033.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''Eleanor A. Magid: Improvisational Bridges.'' Through Nov. 5. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.

UNION COUNTY COLLEGE ''Hella Bailin: Retrospective,'' works by a world-travelling Union resident. Through Oct. 26. Hours: Mondays and Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m.; Tuesdays through Thursdays, 1 to 4 p.m. and 6 to 9 p.m. Tomasulo Art Gallery, Mackay Library, 1033 Springfield Avenue, Cranford. (908) 709-7155.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
For Children
DORBROOK ACTIVITY CENTER ''Fun With French.'' For children 5 to 6 years old. Thursdays at 1 p.m., through Oct. 26. Pre-registration is required. (732) 842-4000.

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE The youth theater group presents: ''Laff-In School; Our Time at Tony's and Brotherhood of Immortals.'' Saturdays at 2 p.m. and Sundays at 12:30 p.m. Through Oct. 8. Tickets at all events: $7.50. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.

FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.'' Through Nov. 4. Performances are every Saturday at 11 a.m.; also this Thursday at 10 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.

MORRIS COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Nature Walks.'' Friday at 9:30 a.m.; Saturday at 5 p.m. Free. ''Mother/Infant Walk: Lewis Morris.'' Tuesday at 9:30 a.m. Free. Pre-registration is required. Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center, 247 Southern Boulevard, Chatham Township. (973) 635-6629.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Ragamala Music and Dance.'' For ages 8 and up. Today at 2 p.m. Bobby Sanabria and Ascension. Saturday at 2 p.m. For ages 12 and up. Tickets: $18; $9 for children. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
STATE THEATER Free Arts Day for Families, featuring ''Baba Yaga and Other Tales.'' Today at 3 p.m. Free; but tickets required to serve seats. 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7469.
Spoken Word

BARNES & NOBLE Carol Singley, an associate professor at Rutgers University's Camden campus, will speak on Edith Wharton's classic novel ''The Age of Innocence'' and her own experience with editing its latest edition. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. 200 West Route 70, Marlton. (856) 225-6026.

BOOKENDS BOOKSTORE Earl Woods, father of Tiger Woods, will discuss and sign a copy of his book ''Start Something: You Can Make a Difference.'' Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Dave Pelzer, author, will discuss and sign a copy of his new book ''Help Yourself: Celebrating the Rewards of Resilience and Gratitude.'' Tuesday at 7 p.m. Free. 232 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 445-0726.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM William C. Agee, professor of art history at Hunter College, will give a lecture entitled ''Cosmic Images in American Art, 1910-1960'' for the museums's annual Babson Lecture. Friday at 2 p.m. Admission: $15; $12 for members. Dr. Bernard Rubin, art collector and conservator, will lecture about ''Secrets Behind Works of Art.'' Saturday at 5 p.m. Free, with admission. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MORRIS MUSEUM Kevin Avery, associate curator of American paintings and sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will give a slide presentation and discussion on ''Art and Nature: The Hudson River School.'' Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for members. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

WILLIAM PATERSON UNIVERSITY Charlie Rose, journalist and talk-show host, will share his experiences in his lecture entitled, ''An Evening With Charlie Rose,'' as part of the 2000-2001 Distinguished Lecturer Series. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $23, $21 for older people; $12 for students. 300 Pompton Road, Wayne. (973) 720-2371.

47TH ANNUAL CHRYSANTHEMUM FLOWER SHOW Saturday, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.; next Sunday, 10 a.m to 5 p.m. Free. Hundreds of prize winning mums are on display; flower arrangements and potted garden mums for sale. Frelinghuysen Arboretum, Haggerty Education Building, 53 East Hanover Avenue, Morristown. (201) 326-7600.

AMERICAN INDIAN ARTS FESTIVAL Saturday through Oct. 9, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. More than 150 artists and entertainers; 50 tribal nations represented. Admission: $10; $5 for older people and children under 12; free for children under 6. Rankokus Indian Reservation, Exit 45A from Interstate 295 or New Jersey Turnpike, Exit 5. Follow signs for Rancocas Road toward Mt. Holly. (609) 261-4747.

NEW JERSEY CITY UNIVERSITY ''Creative Knowing: A Function of Storytelling,'' four-session program for the fall. ''Welsh Stories'' told in English and Welsh by Beth Phillips Brown. Wednesday, 9 a.m. to noon. Free. Grossnickle Auditorium, 2039 Kennedy Boulevard, Jersey City. (201) 200-3214..

NEW JERSEY CONVENTION/EXPO CENTER ''12th Annual New Jersey Fall Boat Show.'' Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Tickets: $7; $5 for children, 12 to 17; free for children under 11. 97 Sunfield Avenue, Edison. (800) 332-3976.

SIX FLAGS GREAT ADVENTURE ''9th Annual Fright Fest.'' Friday evenings, Saturdays and Sundays through Oct. 29. Includes Halloween-themed rides, attractions, shows and a ''Hallowedding'' ceremony on Oct. 13. Free with admission, $43.96 (adult); $21.98 (child). Northern Star Arena, exit 7A off the New Jersey Turnpike. (732) 928-1821.

SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''1770's Living History Festival,'' including working crafts, live music, tours and hay rides. Today, 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Fee: $2 donation (optional). Visitor Center, 190 Lord Stirling Road, Basking Ridge. (908) 766-2489.
WHIPPANY RAILWAY MUSEUM ''Pumpkin Festival.'' Today, 12:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children under 12. Route 10 West and Whippany Road, Whippany. (973) 887-8177.

ATLANTIC CITY HILTON Paul Anka. Friday at 9 p.m.; Saturday at 10 p.m.; next Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $45 and $50. Grand Theater, Boston and Pacific Avenues. (609) 340-7200.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert.'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbra Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.

CLARIDGE HOTEL The Duprees; Jack Fontana, comedian/impressionist (opening act). Friday at 10 p.m.; Saturday at 7:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m.; next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $35. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3400.

TROPICANA ''Tribute to Liberace,'' starring Daryl Wagner; the Lovely Liebowitz Sisters, guests. Tuesday through Dec. 3; call for show times. Tickets: $15. ''Dresses of Diana, Princess of Wales Exhibit.'' Through Dec. 28. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Tickets: $13.95; $11.95 for older people; $6.95 for children, aged 5 to 11. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-3020.
